BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 12, 1920
CALL

Student Council Adopts New Plan
For Enforcing Freshman Attendance at Games.

Beginning with the present
week the Student Council plans
to put into operation an entirely
new method of enforcing freshman attendance at the football
games. The present system of a
roll call before or during the
games has proved ineffective, cumbersome and tedious, and is
therefore to be abandoned. Instead, each freshman who attends
a game will be given a card which
he must wear during the following week to show that he was
present at Homewood on the preceding Saturday. Failure to display a card will arouse the interest of the Sophomores with wellknown consequences.
Any man who expects to be
absent from a game who can show
a valid reason for staying away
will present his case at the
Student Council office in the Barn
during the previous week and receive a card similar to those distributed at the field. It will
therefore be assumed that those
without cards on Monday were
absent from the preceding game
without excuse, and that some
slight assistance on the path to
college spirit is in order. Freshmen who were present at the
Mount St. Mary's game or were
excused will be issued cards on
Monday and Tuesday of this week
and will be expdcted to wear them
on Wednesday.

EDITORIAL COMPETITION
The competition open to students of the University for a
position on the editorial board
opened Monday. At this time
a number of candidates reported, but in order that more
may be secured the NEWS-LETTER office will be open every day
this week between 12.30 and 1
to receive those who wish to
enter the contest. All men interested are requested to come
to the office, so that the conditions governing the competition may be explained.
There is an excellent chance
For all possessing reasonable
editorial or reportorial ability,
as there are many vacancies on
the staff. Those who have had,
in the opinion of the board,
sufficient previous experience,
will be elected within a very
short while.

TEAM PUTS UP PLUCKY FIGHT
Holds Syracuse Eleven to One Touchdown in First Half
—Overwhelmed in Second Half by
Sheer Weight and Numbers
Under a scorching sun, more fitting for a.Fourth of July celebration than for a football game, the Johns Hopkins eleven was defeated
last Saturday by Syracuse University, 45 to 0, on the New Yorkers'
field. Outweighed over 10 pounds to the man, the Black and Blue
fought the big Orange team up and down the fields, and were forced
back only after being worn out by the continuous pounding of heavy
men. The bare statement of the score gives little idea of the great
battle which the Homewood men put up and of the strength of their
game.
During the entire first half the
stiff defense of the Hopkins team
held the Syracuse squad to a single touchdown, scored during the
first quarter after a dash of 50
yards by Abbott, who eluded his
opponents by a fine display of
broken field running. Twice in the
second period the Orange team
worked the ball down the field to
within a few yards of the Hopkins goal, only to be held for
dOWRS or to lose the pigskin on a
fumble. Thus the first half ended
with the count 7-0, and the Syracuse team apparently baffled in
their attempt to run ,up a large
score.
The second half, however, told
a different story. Puzzled by the
failure of his men to pierce the
defense of the far lighter Johns
Hopkins team, Chick Meehan, the
Syracuse coach, sent them back
into the game with orders for a
different style of defense, and
gradually saw the superior weight
and power of his charges sweep
the ball down the field for a succession of touchdown.
Three
times Kellogg crossed the line,
and each time Abbott added another point by kicking goal. In
the final quarter Syracuse scored
twice, each time aided by inopportune fumbles on the part of
Hopkins' back. The final count
for the New Yorkers was registered by Gulick, right tackle for
the Orange team, who scored a
pretty kick from placement from
the 35-yard line.
The game was marked, from a
Syracuse standpoint, by•the great
work of Fallon, Kellogg and Abbott, the latter their all around
star. Hopkins' most consistent
ground-gainer was Calkins, who,
although he made no sensational
plunges, was always ready with
a few yards when they were most
needed. He also did most of the
punting, and made some mighty

fine kicks.
"Jenk" Cromwell
came in for his share of glory
when he battled his 190-pound opponent, Alexander, off his feet during the early part of the game.
Alexander was chosen as all-American guard last year by Walter
Camp. Elmer Jones and Bill
'Wood also did fine work.
Syracuse lost a good deal of
ground by frequent penalties for
holding and for off-side play, while
Johns Hopkins was set back only
once.
While 45 to 0 seems to be, and,
in fact is, an overwhelming score,
there are other points beside the
mere total which should be taken
into account. When -it is remembered that there was such a heavy
advantage in weight on the side
of Syracuse, and that the Orange
team is considered to be one of
the strongest in the country, a
great deal of credit must be given
the Black and Blue for the plucky
tight which it put up and for the
fine game it played in the face of
almost overwhelming odds. Lineup :

PRICE 10 CENTS
LACROSSE SQUAD NOW
ORGANIZED
Promising Material Scarce.
More
Candidates Needed. Schedule
Not Yet Arranged.

The first practice of the 1921
lacrosse team took place on Wednesday afternoon at 4 o'clock. The
team this year has less promising
material than ever before, as there
are very few stars from prep school
and but few regular string men
from last year out for the squad.
It is the aim of the manager and
coaches to have a thorough fall
practice to develop more accurate
stick work, in as much as the material on hand is not up to the
usual standard of the last few
years. Practice will be held three
times a week, on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays on the upper
quadrangle in front of Gilman
Hall. It is decided that complete
lacrosse clothes will not be necessary, as the practice will be centered on stick work and a general work-out, which will provide
a base to start on in the spring.
There will be no attempt at training and men will not be needed
to restrict their diet or to. stop
smoking.
There are some men now practicing with the football team who
will not be able to report for lacrosse until spring, but all others
who wish to make the team next
year will find this practice necessary to develop accuracy in stick
work. Captain Griffiss finds that
there is a notable lack of "lacrosse
brains," which will necessitate
harder and more frequent practices.
BUSINESS COMPETITION
The competition open to students of the University for a position on the businessdepartment
of the Nnws-LETTER will begin
Wednesday. Allstudentsintending to enter this competition
are requested to meet in the office of the NEWS-LETTER at 12.30,
when the work which the candidates are expected to do will
be explained. The competition
will continue until the latter
part of the first term. At the
end of this period either one or
two candidates will be elected.
The choice to be based on business ability, amount of advertising obtained and interest
shown.
At present there are but few
men on the business staff, so
that the competition offers
those interested an excellent
opportunity to become associated with a prominent University activity.

SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB
The Social Science Club was organized in 1918 for the purpose
of studying social and• economic
problems. The club is willing to
consider any plan for the betterment of the social order proposed
by any group of serious and competent students of sociology. The
plan has been to hold a series of
public lectures throughout the
year, each of which is followed by
a discussion meeting the succeeding week. At the discussion meeting, the subject of the lecture is
examined with considerations pro
and con by members of the club.
In addition to the discussion meetings, meetings are held at which
papers on various economic and
social questions are read by members of the club.

and plans will be discussed for
the future policies of the club. A

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWSLETTER, OCTOBER 12, 1920

ONE ACT PLAYS PLANNED
Local Dramatic Club Offers Opportunity to Local Playwrights. Miss
Walter to Coach Again.

THE TURKISH
CIGARETTE

In developing plans for the activities of the coming year, the
Dramatic Club has announced
that much of its effort will be devoted to the production of new
plays written by members of the
university. Such a course will
offer a wonderful opportunity to
those dramatically inclined students who wish, to see their work
on the stage.
During the early part of the
year several one-act plays will be
produced in the club's studio in
the Barn, while the major production of the season will be
staged at the Lyric later in the
winter. Bartus Trew, president
of the club, has again secured the
services of Miss Walter, who
coached the productions of the
last two years so successfully. It
is therefore hoped that every one
who has the germ of a plot and
any skill in writing will submit
his work and thus make possible
the presentation of an "all Hopkins program."

Dr. Jose Robles of the Centro
de Estudios Historicos, Madrid,
Spain, has been appointed instructor in Spanish and lecturer
on modern Spanish literature in
Johns Hopkins University, according to announcement recently
at Homewood.
Professor Robles has been engaged to conduct an advanced
course in the plays of Lope de
Vega, on which he is a recognized
authority. He also will conduct
a course of lectures on "The
Spanish Novel in the Second Half
of the Nineteenth Century," and
will assist with the undergraduate classes in Spanish.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 12, 1920
Y. M. C. A. NOTES
Fund Growing Rapidly.

The efforts of the University Y.
M. C. A. to meet the year's budget
through contributions from the
undergraduate student body have
met with very satisfactory results.
. Though as ,yet incomplete, the
campaign is viewed with unqualified satisfaction due to the unusual readiness which students
have shown in responding to the
appeal.
An attempt will be made during the early part of the week to
meet every one not yet seen, thus
making it an every man campaign.
Among the freshmen practically
all have responded with a substantial pledge, thus continuing
the exhibition of spirit and interest manifested recently at the
freshman reception. The success
of the campaign is accepted as an
indication of the general interest
and approval of this important
branch of our student life.
All who have not done so are
urged to -secure a card and speedily have his contribution—pledge
or money—at the "Y" office .in the
Barn, where Mr. E. Pearce Hayes
or some representative will always be ready to receive such returns.
Foreign Students' Reception.

The V. M. C. A. has arranged
the opening reception of the year
for men from other lands to be
held at the home of Dr. Howard
A. Kelly, 1406 Eutaw Place, Friday, October 15, at 8 P. M. All
students from .lands other than
the United States are asked to be
present. The home of Dr. Kelly
is as complete a museum as one is
able to find anywhere in the city.
One of the important matters
to be taken up at this meeting is
the possibility and advisability of
forming a cosmopolitan club at
the University. At all the other
large important universities in
the United .States there are such
clubs formed with the purpose of
fellowship and exchange of opinions. Most of the foreign students
at John Hopkins visit during the
summer the various nearby universities, where they have seen the
value of such a club, and they
rightly feel that Johns Hopkins
should not fall behind in this matter.
In the University proper there
are this year eighteen foreign
students, representing eight countries, Peru, Spain, Philippine Islands, Mexico, Japan, China, Jamaica and Porto Rico. Practically
all of these men are of prominent
families and are going back to
take conspicuous places in their
countries.

"The Biggest Thing in J. H. U."

MANY

That is what one man called it
last year, and the reference was
to the various classes conducted
among the foreigners of the city,
Russians, Italians, Lithuanians,
Greeks and Poles.
These men are either recent
citizens of the United States or
are trying to prepare themselves
for the citizenship examinations.
Most of them are unable to read
or write and know practically
nothing of the working ot the national Government.
Classes in
English and the rudiments of the
United States Government are
taught; at the same time the effort is made to interpret the best
in American life.
. The University Y. M. C. A. is
planning this winter to conduct
many such classes with these men,
all to be led by Hopkins undergraduates. The total number of
students needed will be about
fifty. These men will be asked to
give one night a week to help in
this constructive program to offset
the social unrest among the unAmericanized foreigners in our
midst. Any man who is interested
should see Mr. Hayes at the Y.
M. C. A. office in the Barn.
Handbook.

There are just a few men who
have not as yet secured their
handbooks and the same may be
secured, free of charge, at the Y.
M. C. A. office in the Barn. Every
man should carry his "Freshman
Bible" so as to have on hand at
all times a ready reference to all
the campus activities.
Results.

That's what we are all interested in. If it brings results, we
say that the thing is worth while,
and we are back of it. Here are
some of the results of the first
week's effort of the Lost and
Found Bureau, just recently established at the University: Twenty-seven articles have been returned to the owner from a total
of forty-two articles found. This
leaves a balance of fifteen articles
still unclaimed.
This bureau can be of great
value to you if you will promptly
report to the bureau any article
lost or found.

CANDIDATES
MUSICAL CLUB

FOR

The Medical Standard Book Co.
( THE BOOK MART)

Much Promising Material Obtained.
Successful Season Seems
Assured.

The Musical Club held its organization meeting on Tuesday,
October 5, at 8 P.M., in the C. E.
Building. More than fifty men
were present as .candidates either
for the Glee Club or the Instrumental Club. This large number
of candidates will make greater
competition and will insure a club
that will be better than that of
last year.
The prospects of a
snappy jazz band seem excellent
as two saxophones and a clarinet
will be added to the other instruments and will make synchopated
music to rival any of its kind. As
there are a somewhat limited
number of guitars the competition
among the mandolins will be
strong. The Glee Club is fortunate in the great number of first
tenors who have come out. These
are usually scarce and have to be
sought for personally by the management. The other parts are well
represented. Several new, original and clever individual stunts
will be used to complete a program which will put the Musical
Club of Hopkins on a plane higher
than that ever obtained.
The prospect of a successful season, with a fine representative
showing at every concert is highly
encouraging. The opportunity to
join is still open. Every man with
any musical ability or knowledge
of some clever individual stunt is
heartily urged to attend the rehearsals and is assured an opportunity to make the club. Meet• ings from now on will be held in
the C. E. Hall every Tuesday night
at 7 o'clock.

Hats off to Van Orman and his
warriors! That's the kind of fight
we like to see. In both games so
far this season the team has shown
what kind of guts they have, and
have shown it with credit to themselves.
Last week, after a terrible case
of stage fright and a couple of
flukes had handicapped them seemingly beyond reprieve, they dug in
and came through with a victory
which was a treat to witness.
Outweighed about 15 pounds to
the man, and playing against one
of the strongest football machines
in the country, the Black and Blue
put up the fight of their lives
against Syracuse. Except for a
sort of fluke, the 50-yard run of
Abbott, the Varsity held her opponents scoreless for one-half of
the contest.
But weight and greater experience are bound to tell in the end,
so the rather large score in this
case means almost nothing.
The team fought all the way
against great odds, many times
holding the powerful New York
team in check at crucial moments, and, in their turn, bucking
the Syracuse lines for several first
downs.
If the team continues to fight
her way thus through the remainder of the season, Johns Hopkins
will have every cause to be justly
proud of, her football team.
Here's to you, Van Orman, Hopkins if3 behind you! Give us a
fighting team and we will be satisfied.
While commending the spirit of
the eleven, let us not overlook the
fine turnout to bid the team Godspeed last Thursday.
Hopkins is awakening! The
presence of over half the student
body, giving them a hearty sendoff, we feel, was in large measure
a tonic to the men about to journey
to Syracuse to face almost certain
defeat.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 12, 1920
CALL

Student Council Adopts New Plan
For Enforcing Freshman Attendance at Games.

Beginning with the present
week the Student Council plans
to put into operation an entirely
new method of enforcing freshman attendance at the football
games. The present system of a
roll call before or during the
games has proved ineffective, cumbersome and tedious, and is
therefore to be abandoned. Instead, each freshman who attends
a game will be given a card which
he must wear during the following week to show that he was
present at Homewood on the preceding Saturday. Failure to display a card will arouse the interest of the Sophomores with wellknown consequences.
Any man who expects to be
absent from a game who can show
a valid reason for staying away
will present his case at the
Student Council office in the Barn
during the previous week and receive a card similar to those distributed at the field. It will
therefore be assumed that those
without cards on Monday were
absent from the preceding game
without excuse, and that some
slight assistance on the path to
college spirit is in order. Freshmen who were present at the
Mount St. Mary's game or were
excused will be issued cards on
Monday and Tuesday of this week
and will be expdcted to wear them
on Wednesday.

EDITORIAL COMPETITION
The competition open to students of the University for a
position on the editorial board
opened Monday. At this time
a number of candidates reported, but in order that more
may be secured the NEWS-LETTER office will be open every day
this week between 12.30 and 1
to receive those who wish to
enter the contest. All men interested are requested to come
to the office, so that the conditions governing the competition may be explained.
There is an excellent chance
For all possessing reasonable
editorial or reportorial ability,
as there are many vacancies on
the staff. Those who have had,
in the opinion of the board,
sufficient previous experience,
will be elected within a very
short while.

TEAM PUTS UP PLUCKY FIGHT
Holds Syracuse Eleven to One Touchdown in First Half
—Overwhelmed in Second Half by
Sheer Weight and Numbers
Under a scorching sun, more fitting for a.Fourth of July celebration than for a football game, the Johns Hopkins eleven was defeated
last Saturday by Syracuse University, 45 to 0, on the New Yorkers'
field. Outweighed over 10 pounds to the man, the Black and Blue
fought the big Orange team up and down the fields, and were forced
back only after being worn out by the continuous pounding of heavy
men. The bare statement of the score gives little idea of the great
battle which the Homewood men put up and of the strength of their
game.
During the entire first half the
stiff defense of the Hopkins team
held the Syracuse squad to a single touchdown, scored during the
first quarter after a dash of 50
yards by Abbott, who eluded his
opponents by a fine display of
broken field running. Twice in the
second period the Orange team
worked the ball down the field to
within a few yards of the Hopkins goal, only to be held for
dOWRS or to lose the pigskin on a
fumble. Thus the first half ended
with the count 7-0, and the Syracuse team apparently baffled in
their attempt to run ,up a large
score.
The second half, however, told
a different story. Puzzled by the
failure of his men to pierce the
defense of the far lighter Johns
Hopkins team, Chick Meehan, the
Syracuse coach, sent them back
into the game with orders for a
different style of defense, and
gradually saw the superior weight
and power of his charges sweep
the ball down the field for a succession of touchdown.
Three
times Kellogg crossed the line,
and each time Abbott added another point by kicking goal. In
the final quarter Syracuse scored
twice, each time aided by inopportune fumbles on the part of
Hopkins' back. The final count
for the New Yorkers was registered by Gulick, right tackle for
the Orange team, who scored a
pretty kick from placement from
the 35-yard line.
The game was marked, from a
Syracuse standpoint, by•the great
work of Fallon, Kellogg and Abbott, the latter their all around
star. Hopkins' most consistent
ground-gainer was Calkins, who,
although he made no sensational
plunges, was always ready with
a few yards when they were most
needed. He also did most of the
punting, and made some mighty

fine kicks.
"Jenk" Cromwell
came in for his share of glory
when he battled his 190-pound opponent, Alexander, off his feet during the early part of the game.
Alexander was chosen as all-American guard last year by Walter
Camp. Elmer Jones and Bill
'Wood also did fine work.
Syracuse lost a good deal of
ground by frequent penalties for
holding and for off-side play, while
Johns Hopkins was set back only
once.
While 45 to 0 seems to be, and,
in fact is, an overwhelming score,
there are other points beside the
mere total which should be taken
into account. When -it is remembered that there was such a heavy
advantage in weight on the side
of Syracuse, and that the Orange
team is considered to be one of
the strongest in the country, a
great deal of credit must be given
the Black and Blue for the plucky
tight which it put up and for the
fine game it played in the face of
almost overwhelming odds. Lineup :

PRICE 10 CENTS
LACROSSE SQUAD NOW
ORGANIZED
Promising Material Scarce.
More
Candidates Needed. Schedule
Not Yet Arranged.

The first practice of the 1921
lacrosse team took place on Wednesday afternoon at 4 o'clock. The
team this year has less promising
material than ever before, as there
are very few stars from prep school
and but few regular string men
from last year out for the squad.
It is the aim of the manager and
coaches to have a thorough fall
practice to develop more accurate
stick work, in as much as the material on hand is not up to the
usual standard of the last few
years. Practice will be held three
times a week, on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays on the upper
quadrangle in front of Gilman
Hall. It is decided that complete
lacrosse clothes will not be necessary, as the practice will be centered on stick work and a general work-out, which will provide
a base to start on in the spring.
There will be no attempt at training and men will not be needed
to restrict their diet or to. stop
smoking.
There are some men now practicing with the football team who
will not be able to report for lacrosse until spring, but all others
who wish to make the team next
year will find this practice necessary to develop accuracy in stick
work. Captain Griffiss finds that
there is a notable lack of "lacrosse
brains," which will necessitate
harder and more frequent practices.
BUSINESS COMPETITION
The competition open to students of the University for a position on the businessdepartment
of the Nnws-LETTER will begin
Wednesday. Allstudentsintending to enter this competition
are requested to meet in the office of the NEWS-LETTER at 12.30,
when the work which the candidates are expected to do will
be explained. The competition
will continue until the latter
part of the first term. At the
end of this period either one or
two candidates will be elected.
The choice to be based on business ability, amount of advertising obtained and interest
shown.
At present there are but few
men on the business staff, so
that the competition offers
those interested an excellent
opportunity to become associated with a prominent University activity.

SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB
The Social Science Club was organized in 1918 for the purpose
of studying social and• economic
problems. The club is willing to
consider any plan for the betterment of the social order proposed
by any group of serious and competent students of sociology. The
plan has been to hold a series of
public lectures throughout the
year, each of which is followed by
a discussion meeting the succeeding week. At the discussion meeting, the subject of the lecture is
examined with considerations pro
and con by members of the club.
In addition to the discussion meetings, meetings are held at which
papers on various economic and
social questions are read by members of the club.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWSLETTER, OCTOBER 12, 1920

ONE ACT PLAYS PLANNED
Local Dramatic Club Offers Opportunity to Local Playwrights. Miss
Walter to Coach Again.

THE TURKISH
CIGARETTE

In developing plans for the activities of the coming year, the
Dramatic Club has announced
that much of its effort will be devoted to the production of new
plays written by members of the
university. Such a course will
offer a wonderful opportunity to
those dramatically inclined students who wish, to see their work
on the stage.
During the early part of the
year several one-act plays will be
produced in the club's studio in
the Barn, while the major production of the season will be
staged at the Lyric later in the
winter. Bartus Trew, president
of the club, has again secured the
services of Miss Walter, who
coached the productions of the
last two years so successfully. It
is therefore hoped that every one
who has the germ of a plot and
any skill in writing will submit
his work and thus make possible
the presentation of an "all Hopkins program."

Dr. Jose Robles of the Centro
de Estudios Historicos, Madrid,
Spain, has been appointed instructor in Spanish and lecturer
on modern Spanish literature in
Johns Hopkins University, according to announcement recently
at Homewood.
Professor Robles has been engaged to conduct an advanced
course in the plays of Lope de
Vega, on which he is a recognized
authority. He also will conduct
a course of lectures on "The
Spanish Novel in the Second Half
of the Nineteenth Century," and
will assist with the undergraduate classes in Spanish.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 12, 1920
Y. M. C. A. NOTES
Fund Growing Rapidly.

The efforts of the University Y.
M. C. A. to meet the year's budget
through contributions from the
undergraduate student body have
met with very satisfactory results.
. Though as ,yet incomplete, the
campaign is viewed with unqualified satisfaction due to the unusual readiness which students
have shown in responding to the
appeal.
An attempt will be made during the early part of the week to
meet every one not yet seen, thus
making it an every man campaign.
Among the freshmen practically
all have responded with a substantial pledge, thus continuing
the exhibition of spirit and interest manifested recently at the
freshman reception. The success
of the campaign is accepted as an
indication of the general interest
and approval of this important
branch of our student life.
All who have not done so are
urged to -secure a card and speedily have his contribution—pledge
or money—at the "Y" office .in the
Barn, where Mr. E. Pearce Hayes
or some representative will always be ready to receive such returns.
Foreign Students' Reception.

The V. M. C. A. has arranged
the opening reception of the year
for men from other lands to be
held at the home of Dr. Howard
A. Kelly, 1406 Eutaw Place, Friday, October 15, at 8 P. M. All
students from .lands other than
the United States are asked to be
present. The home of Dr. Kelly
is as complete a museum as one is
able to find anywhere in the city.
One of the important matters
to be taken up at this meeting is
the possibility and advisability of
forming a cosmopolitan club at
the University. At all the other
large important universities in
the United .States there are such
clubs formed with the purpose of
fellowship and exchange of opinions. Most of the foreign students
at John Hopkins visit during the
summer the various nearby universities, where they have seen the
value of such a club, and they
rightly feel that Johns Hopkins
should not fall behind in this matter.
In the University proper there
are this year eighteen foreign
students, representing eight countries, Peru, Spain, Philippine Islands, Mexico, Japan, China, Jamaica and Porto Rico. Practically
all of these men are of prominent
families and are going back to
take conspicuous places in their
countries.

"The Biggest Thing in J. H. U."

MANY

That is what one man called it
last year, and the reference was
to the various classes conducted
among the foreigners of the city,
Russians, Italians, Lithuanians,
Greeks and Poles.
These men are either recent
citizens of the United States or
are trying to prepare themselves
for the citizenship examinations.
Most of them are unable to read
or write and know practically
nothing of the working ot the national Government.
Classes in
English and the rudiments of the
United States Government are
taught; at the same time the effort is made to interpret the best
in American life.
. The University Y. M. C. A. is
planning this winter to conduct
many such classes with these men,
all to be led by Hopkins undergraduates. The total number of
students needed will be about
fifty. These men will be asked to
give one night a week to help in
this constructive program to offset
the social unrest among the unAmericanized foreigners in our
midst. Any man who is interested
should see Mr. Hayes at the Y.
M. C. A. office in the Barn.
Handbook.

There are just a few men who
have not as yet secured their
handbooks and the same may be
secured, free of charge, at the Y.
M. C. A. office in the Barn. Every
man should carry his "Freshman
Bible" so as to have on hand at
all times a ready reference to all
the campus activities.
Results.

That's what we are all interested in. If it brings results, we
say that the thing is worth while,
and we are back of it. Here are
some of the results of the first
week's effort of the Lost and
Found Bureau, just recently established at the University: Twenty-seven articles have been returned to the owner from a total
of forty-two articles found. This
leaves a balance of fifteen articles
still unclaimed.
This bureau can be of great
value to you if you will promptly
report to the bureau any article
lost or found.

CANDIDATES
MUSICAL CLUB

FOR

The Medical Standard Book Co.
( THE BOOK MART)

Much Promising Material Obtained.
Successful Season Seems
Assured.

The Musical Club held its organization meeting on Tuesday,
October 5, at 8 P.M., in the C. E.
Building. More than fifty men
were present as .candidates either
for the Glee Club or the Instrumental Club. This large number
of candidates will make greater
competition and will insure a club
that will be better than that of
last year.
The prospects of a
snappy jazz band seem excellent
as two saxophones and a clarinet
will be added to the other instruments and will make synchopated
music to rival any of its kind. As
there are a somewhat limited
number of guitars the competition
among the mandolins will be
strong. The Glee Club is fortunate in the great number of first
tenors who have come out. These
are usually scarce and have to be
sought for personally by the management. The other parts are well
represented. Several new, original and clever individual stunts
will be used to complete a program which will put the Musical
Club of Hopkins on a plane higher
than that ever obtained.
The prospect of a successful season, with a fine representative
showing at every concert is highly
encouraging. The opportunity to
join is still open. Every man with
any musical ability or knowledge
of some clever individual stunt is
heartily urged to attend the rehearsals and is assured an opportunity to make the club. Meet• ings from now on will be held in
the C. E. Hall every Tuesday night
at 7 o'clock.

Hats off to Van Orman and his
warriors! That's the kind of fight
we like to see. In both games so
far this season the team has shown
what kind of guts they have, and
have shown it with credit to themselves.
Last week, after a terrible case
of stage fright and a couple of
flukes had handicapped them seemingly beyond reprieve, they dug in
and came through with a victory
which was a treat to witness.
Outweighed about 15 pounds to
the man, and playing against one
of the strongest football machines
in the country, the Black and Blue
put up the fight of their lives
against Syracuse. Except for a
sort of fluke, the 50-yard run of
Abbott, the Varsity held her opponents scoreless for one-half of
the contest.
But weight and greater experience are bound to tell in the end,
so the rather large score in this
case means almost nothing.
The team fought all the way
against great odds, many times
holding the powerful New York
team in check at crucial moments, and, in their turn, bucking
the Syracuse lines for several first
downs.
If the team continues to fight
her way thus through the remainder of the season, Johns Hopkins
will have every cause to be justly
proud of, her football team.
Here's to you, Van Orman, Hopkins if3 behind you! Give us a
fighting team and we will be satisfied.
While commending the spirit of
the eleven, let us not overlook the
fine turnout to bid the team Godspeed last Thursday.
Hopkins is awakening! The
presence of over half the student
body, giving them a hearty sendoff, we feel, was in large measure
a tonic to the men about to journey
to Syracuse to face almost certain
defeat.
